results.title: The Fifth element [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Gaumont-British Instructional, Columbia, Patrick Ledoux and Luc Besson
results.brief_description: The Fifth Element takes an amazing glimpse into the future, with wonderful visual effects from the people who gave us “Titanic”, “Nikita” and “The Professional”, and unique costumes by visionary designer, Jean-Paul Gaultier. If the four elements are fire, water, earth and air, what is the Fifth element? What does it do? Who has control of it? These questions and others are answered as the film unfolds at a breath taking pace. This film takes you on a sci-fi thrill ride of the decade. Bruce Willis, a taxi-driver in New York city in the 23rd Century is selected as our hero. He will travel to the end of the galaxy to decide the fate of our universe. Cast includes Gary Oldman, Milla Jovovich, Ian Holm and Chris Tucker.

results.title: The Fallen idol
results.creator_credit: London Film Productions, David O. Selznick and Carol Reed
results.brief_description: An ambassador’s small son nearly incriminates his friend the butler in the accidental death of his shrewish wife. A near-perfect piece of small-scale cinema, built up from clever nuances of acting and cinematic technique. Written by Graham Greene. Stars Ralph Richardson. Rated: PG

results.title: The Falcon and the snowman
results.creator_credit: Orion Pictures Corporation, Gabriel Katzka and John Schlesinger
results.brief_description: A seminary drop out and aimless youth, Christopher Boyce (Timothy Hutton) is an average American who commences work at RTX as a sensitive document handler. Chris is quickly earmarked for something significant, working with the CIA in monitoring special projects. Occasionally he also intercepts misrouted secret mail. Disillusioned with the deceptions he comes across, Chris enlists the help of his (originally reluctant) drug dealing best friend Andrew Daulton Lee (Sean Penn) to act as go between in selling secrets to the Russian KGB. Lee’s dealings with the KGB are mainly with a Russian spy (David Suchet) who doesn’t underestimate the naivete of the people he is dealing with and is quick to raise the stakes in what he’s willing to pay for. Lee, high on his addiction to crack and being flush with money to support his habit, attempts to subvert the exchanges to his advantage and is liberal in sharing their secret with all and sundry - jeopardising his friendship and their discovery. Based on a true story and set against a backdrop of Nixon’s impeachment, the film has been read as a metaphor for the disillusion felt throughout America in the 1970s and the search for meaning in a time of Vietnam, the Cold War and political mistrust, balanced against advances in space exploration and artistic and sexual freedom. Cast also includes Pat Hingle, Joyce Van Patten and Lori Singer.

results.title: The Fabulous Baker boys
results.creator_credit: Mirage Enterprises, Gladden Entertainment, Mark Rosenberg, Paula Weinstein and Steve Kloves
results.brief_description: The Baker brothers, Frank and Jack, have been playing together for thirty-one years, as piano accompanists, in an array of bars and nightclubs. In the throes of a dead-end career, the cynical Jack is particularly embittered by their lack of success and thwarted dreams of glory that has resulted in a slew of bad gigs at sleazy dives. Frank, a responsible father of two who worries for their finances, is willing to take any gig for a buck. But Jack is resentful of Frank’s passivity and inability to defend his honour or art. Increasingly unemployable, the brothers hire a singer to spruce up their act - and Susie Diamond, ballsy, rough, lower class but talented, transforms them into a classy act. The alluring presence of the sexy Susie creates tensions for the brothers who are forced to address the inequities and rivalry that mars their relationship. Although the formula of the outsider who upsets the dynamics of a long-standing show-biz relationship has been used frequently in cinema, “The Fabulous Baker boys” still engages and entertains, greatly assisted by the stellar performances of the leads, Jeff and Beau Bridges and Michelle Pfeiffer and an array of sultry tunes.

results.title: The Exorcist [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Warner Bros Pictures, William Peter Blatty and William Friedkin
results.brief_description: The Exorcist occupies a central position in the history of horror films, an almost sadistically malevolent experience in terror. Regan (Linda Blair) is a young girl entering puberty and she becomes possessed by the spirit of an ancient demon. Her mother (Ellen Burstyn) finds that there is no assistance in the scientific pragmatism of the modern world and she hesitantly turns to the occult rites of Catholicism and Orthodoxy in order to rid her daughter of the monster. The exorcism scenes attain a disturbing authenticity and they are based on the official Catholic Church rites of exorcism. “The Exorcist” is a film that feeds on our most intimate fears and terrors and not a film for the easily frightened. Stars Max Van Sydow as Father Merrin. Based on the book by William Peter Blatty. Mercedes McCambridge is the voice of the Devil. Part of Tubular Bell by Mike Oldfield used on the soundtrack.

results.title: The Evil dead (D)
results.creator_credit: Renaissance, Robert Tapert and Sam Raimi
results.brief_description: The Evil dead emerges as the ultimate in low-budget gore and shock effects. Story premise has five youngsters holed up in a remote cabin where they discover a Book of the Dead. An archaeologists tape recording reveals it having been found among the Khandarian ruins of a Sumerian civilization. Playing the taped incantations unwittingly summons up dormant demons living in the nearby forest, which possesses the youngsters in succession until there is only Ash (Bruce Campbell) left to fight for his survival. While injecting considerable black humour, neophyte Detroit-based writer-director Sam Raimi maintains suspense and a nightmarish mood in between showy outbursts of special effects gore and graphic violence which are staples of modern horror pictures. Powerful camerawork suggests the lurking presence of the huge-scale demons in the forest. Filmed in 1980 at Tennessee and Michigan locations for under $400,000, this is a grainy blowup from 16mm film.

results.title: The Entity
results.creator_credit: American Cinema Productions, Pelleport Investors, Harold Schneider and Sidney J. Furie
results.brief_description: This horror/haunted house/poltergeist movie is based on a true story of a woman who was harassed by inexplicable forces. Carla Moran (Barbara Hershey) is a caring mother who lives with her children, when she is repeatedly and brutally raped by an unseen entity, and besieged by other inconceivable events that petrify her. Carla is increasingly isolated (even ridiculed) for her experiences, which rack her emotionally and physically. When she seeks professional help, a team of psychiatrists study Carla’s situation seeking to unravel the source of her terror. Some sceptics in the team believe it to be female hysteria even insanity, but one kindly doctor, Phil Schneidermann (Ron Silver) is convinced of her sincerity and is determined to aid her plight with science and a parapsychological approach. At times genuinely terrifying, this film is somewhat dated, particularly in the special effects department, but interestingly was released just a year before Spielberg’s hugely successful “Poltergeist”, with which it shares many major themes. Hershey puts in a fine performance as an imperilled woman whose ordinary (if bleak) life is put under siege by forces beyond her comprehension. Although the film takes a somewhat dissatisfying turn mid-way through, it remains an interesting example of a science versus spirit movie and should prove a boon to horror buffs.

results.title: The Enigma of Kaspar Hauser = Jeder fur sich und Gott gegen alle
results.creator_credit: Werner Herzog Filmproduktion, Walter Saxer and Werner Herzog
results.brief_description: Regarded as Herzog’s finest film, “The Enigma of Kasper Hauser” is based on a true story about a 19th Century genius. His origins shrouded in mystery, Kasper Hauser was found wandering the streets of Nuremberg in 1820. Without speech, nor any sign of parentage, Hauser immediately becomes the object of scrutiny from the town authorities. After learning to talk he tells of living in a cellar, displaying no signs of having had any contact with other human beings since childhood. In his attempts to adjust to adult life, he reveals a highly advanced intelligence and alternative, almost prophetic, vision. Herzog demonstrates his fascination with misfits, and as the story develops, the confrontation between innocence and corruption intensifies. Cast includes Bruno S, Walter Ladengast and Brigitte Mira. In German with English subtitles.
